channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Will North Korea defend China in a Taiwan war?
item.description: Pyongyang’s contribution to Moscow’s war against Ukraine means a difficult question needs to be asked in the event shooting starts.

item.title: China’s Messy History With Mongolia
item.description: The countries’ ethnic ties have grown strained in recent years.

item.title: New Uncertainty Shadows Gaza’s Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: After the exchange of hostages and prisoners, Israel and Hamas now move to the daunting task of establishing a lasting peace.

item.title: The costs of dating your boss
item.description: New research shows breakups come with big wage penalties

item.title: Democrats collapsed in the shutdown fight
item.description: They have little to show for 40 days of fighting

item.title: China Makes a Tech Splash in Portugal
item.description: Beijing dabbles in diplomacy at Web Summit.

item.title: Tehran’s Residents Are Panicking as Taps Run Dry
item.description: Years of drought and neglect have left the city nearly unsustainable.

item.title: Putin Will Never Compromise on Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s president is too committed to his own fantasies to ever accept Ukraine’s independence.

item.title: The promise and the perils of using AI for therapy
item.description: Millions are already turning to the technology for mental-health care

item.title: Old folk are seized by stockmarket mania
item.description: Investing in equities may make sense for individuals—but it could also exacerbate a crash

item.title: Canadian Ostriches Have Become Martyrs for the U.S. Right
item.description: How a fight over culling birds turned into an anti-government flash point.

item.title: Beijing insiders’ plan to play Donald Trump
item.description: They see America’s president as a golden opportunity for China

item.title: Trump’s Russia Sanctions Are Really Putting the Hurt On
item.description: He was late to the show, but he brought a big stick.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Threaten the End of Neutrality
item.description: Now even Switzerland can’t escape great-power politics.

item.title: The Key to Unlocking Climate Progress
item.description: When it comes to meeting the targets outlined in the Paris climate agreement, what ultimately matters is whether finance enables implementation of promises already made. That means building the state capacity that will translate national sustainable-development plans into measurable outcomes.

item.title: How COP30 Can Re-Energize Climate Action
item.description: Policymakers gathering for the UN Climate Change Conference in Belém this month should feel a sense of collective responsibility to confront the alarming gap between what countries have put on the table and what is urgently required. Fortunately, this summit is the perfect occasion to achieve new breakthroughs.

item.title: Yemen’s generation without classrooms
item.description: A decade of war and humanitarian crisis has cratered Yemen’s education system for girls.

item.title: How China Became a Solar Power
item.description: Beijing’s green energy ambitions are fueling a global revolution.

item.title: Despite claims, foreign students have not yet been put off America
item.description: Our analysis shows that a reported dip in arrivals this year may be a mirage

item.title: What Bill Gates Overlooks About Climate Change
item.description: Bill Gates recently argued that we should de-emphasize the existential threat posed by climate change in order to “put human welfare at the center of our climate strategies.” But how tolerant should we be of the risk of creating a climate that will be disastrous for human welfare for centuries to come?

item.title: The AI Labor Shock Is Coming for Women
item.description: Women comprise the majority of workers in more than half of the 40 occupations that are most at risk of displacement by AI. In the near term, political and business leaders can prevent female workers from becoming collateral damage by ensuring that they are offered equal opportunities for access and upskilling.

item.title: Modi and the Mullahs: India’s Embrace of the Taliban
item.description: Why is New Delhi’s approach to the Islamist fundamentalist group is so different this time around?

item.title: Syria joins the American-led fight against Islamic State
item.description: But some in Ahmed al-Sharaa’s ranks still sympathise with the jihadists

item.title: The Nostalgic Delusion of 1989
item.description: The U.S. military buildup around Venezuela has drawn comparisons to past regime change in Panama. But Washington cannot invade its way to democracy in Caracas.

item.title: This Is the Future of U.S. Foreign Aid Under Trump
item.description: Post-USAID assistance may depend on a country’s strategic value to Washington.

item.title: A New Economic Playbook for Policymakers
item.description: The Washington Consensus assumed that economic growth would automatically follow market liberalization. That belief has not aged well, and a new policy approach must include innovation, good jobs, climate stability, gender equality, and a state empowered to provide effective regulation and high-quality public services.

item.title: What to Make of the Recent Trump-Xi Summit?
item.description: Have the two powers found a new framework for relations?

item.title: The War Room newsletter: Nuremberg 80 years on, a reckoning
item.description: Rosie Blau, co-host of “The Intelligence”, examines post-war accountability and retribution

item.title: The Would-Be Dictator’s Army
item.description: The United States is about to celebrate a very worrisome Veterans Day.

item.title: Massive Car Explosion Rocks India’s Capital
item.description: If the bombing turns out to be a terrorist act, India can be expected to retaliate robustly, even to escalate retaliation.

item.title: Breaking Down the Philippines’ 2026 Budget
item.description: Economic growth in the Philippines remains on a solid trajectory, but the government has struggled in recent years to reduce its budget deficit.

item.title: A Hidden Hunger Crisis Is Destabilizing the World
item.description: Food insecurity provokes violence—and weakens even wealthy states.

item.title: Ukraine’s Hardest Winter
item.description: With the Donbas in peril, Europe must pressure Russia now.

item.title: Eve Warburton on Indonesian President Prabowo’s First Year in Office
item.description: The former general is building on what his predecessor Joko Widodo left behind, furthering the country's "gradual illiberal slide."
